question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Oh, Serena, you always have a way of asking the most obvious questions. Of course, I care about making a good impression. In fact, I pride myself on it. It's not just about being liked, it's about being respected and admired. People should know that when Blair Waldorf enters a room, she commands attention and leaves a lasting impression. It's all part of being a true socialite, darling.

question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Oh, Serena, always trying to psychoanalyze me, aren't you? Well, let me enlighten you. While I do appreciate the charm of quiet, intimate places, I am naturally drawn to the energy and excitement of busy, bustling atmospheres. After all, I thrive in the spotlight and crave the attention of the social scene. It's where I feel most alive and in my element. So, yes, I do feel more drawn to those vibrant, lively places. But don't mistake it for a lack of appreciation for the quieter moments. I can appreciate both, thank you very much.

question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Oh, Serena, darling, you know I never shy away from a chance to strike up a conversation with someone intriguing. It's practically second nature to me. After all, why wait for fate to bring us together when I can take matters into my own hands? Confidence is key, my dear, and I have it in abundance. So yes, I feel more than comfortable approaching someone I find interesting and engaging them in a captivating conversation. It's all part of my charm.

question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
response_open: Oh, Serena, darling, you always have a way of asking the most amusing questions. While it may be true that I prefer the company of those who are already familiar to me, it's not because I lack the ability to introduce myself to new people. It's simply a matter of prioritizing my time and energy. After all, why waste precious moments on insignificant encounters when I can focus on cultivating meaningful connections with those who truly matter? Quality over quantity, my dear. That's the Blair Waldorf way.

question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Well, Serena, it's clear that you still don't understand the concept of priorities. Of course, getting back on track is always my top priority. I don't let anything or anyone derail my plans. I am a woman of ambition and determination, and I will stop at nothing to achieve my goals. So yes, getting back on track as soon as possible is non-negotiable for me.

question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Oh, Serena, always trying to analyze my work style, aren't you? Well, let me enlighten you. My personal work style is a perfect blend of meticulous planning and strategic execution. I believe in putting in consistent efforts, but I also know how to seize spontaneous opportunities when they arise. After all, success doesn't just happen by chance, it's a result of careful calculation and impeccable taste. So, while I may have bursts of energy, they are always channeled into organized and well-thought-out endeavors.

question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Oh, Serena, always questioning my choices, aren't you? Well, let me tell you something, darling. I may have made some mistakes along the way, but I never second-guess myself. I make decisions with confidence and conviction. It's what sets me apart from the rest. So, no, I don't second-guess my choices. I own them and make them work in my favor. That's the Blair Waldorf way.

question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
response_open: Oh, Serena, darling, you always have such interesting questions. Well, when it comes to projects, I do believe in giving my full attention and dedication to one at a time. After all, quality over quantity, right? It's important to focus on each endeavor and ensure that it's executed flawlessly. So, yes, I do prefer to completely finish one project before moving on to the next. It's all about maintaining a sense of control and perfection, just like a true Waldorf.

question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Oh, Serena, overwhelmed is a word for the weak. I am never overwhelmed. I am a master of multitasking and handling any situation that comes my way. I thrive under pressure and always come out on top. So, no, I do not feel overwhelmed. I am in control of my life at all times.

question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Oh, Serena, you always have a knack for bringing up the past, don't you? But yes, I must admit, there are certain mistakes that still haunt me. After all, I am only human, and even the Queen Bee can make missteps. But what sets me apart is that I learn from those mistakes and strive to become a better version of myself. So yes, while I may be bothered by them, I use them as fuel to propel me forward and ensure I never repeat them again. After all, dwelling on the past is so pass√©. It's all about embracing the present and creating a future that is worthy of my fabulousness.

question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Well, Serena, unlike you, I have always prided myself on my ability to stay calm and composed in any situation. Pressure is just another opportunity for me to showcase my grace and poise. After all, a true queen never lets the weight of the world bring her down. So yes, I do stay calm under pressure, because that's what separates me from the rest of the mere mortals.

question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
response_open: Oh, Serena, how predictable of you to assume that I spend my free time on such trivial pursuits. While I do have a keen intellect and a thirst for knowledge, my interests are far from random. I prefer to engage in activities that align with my refined tastes and sophisticated sensibilities. Whether it's attending exclusive art exhibitions, indulging in high-end fashion, or socializing with the elite of society, my time is far too valuable to be wasted on frivolous exploration. But I suppose it's no surprise that you would find fascination in such mundane endeavors. After all, you've always been one to chase after the latest trend, rather than cultivating true refinement.

question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Oh, Serena, always trying to sound intellectual. But let's be honest, discussing interpretations and analyses of creative works is just a way for people to pretend they're deep and cultured. I prefer to focus on the more important things in life, like fashion, social status, and making sure everyone knows who's in charge. So, no, I'm not too interested in discussing interpretations and analyses. But if you want to talk about the latest fashion trends or the scandalous gossip circulating the Upper East Side, then I'm all ears.

question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
response_open: Blair Waldorf: Oh, Serena, always the one to bring up my worries. But let me assure you, worrying is for the weak. I don't waste my time fretting over potential misfortunes. I prefer to focus on taking control of my destiny and ensuring that things turn out in my favor. So, no, I am not prone to worrying. I am prone to making things happen.

question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
response_open: Oh, Serena, always trying to sound deep and philosophical. Well, let me enlighten you. Contemplating the meaning of life is a luxury reserved for those who have already conquered the trivialities of existence. As for me, I have more important things to focus on, like maintaining my social status and ruling the Upper East Side. So, no, I don't waste my time pondering such existential questions. Life is meant to be lived, not analyzed. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a society event to attend. Ta-ta!
